body_html:
I agree with @tatatodd .
In the example above, we create two structures by condition in fact. I believe that reproducibility is only guaranteed for one deterministic structure, say, results always are same for toggle=True or toggle=False.

Even though we switch to use tensor name, we'll still meet the dilemma if only structure is changed:

c0 = ...

if toggle:
   v1 = tf.Variable(...)
   c1 = ...
else:
   c2 = ...

v = tf.Variable(...)  # undetermined
body_text:
I agree with @tatatodd .
In the example above, we create two structures by condition in fact. I believe that reproducibility is only guaranteed for one deterministic structure, say, results always are same for toggle=True or toggle=False.
Even though we switch to use tensor name, we'll still meet the dilemma if only structure is changed:
c0 = ...

if toggle:
   v1 = tf.Variable(...)
   c1 = ...
else:
   c2 = ...

v = tf.Variable(...)  # undetermined
body:
I agree with @tatatodd . 
In the example above, we create two structures by condition in fact. I believe that reproducibility is only guaranteed for one deterministic structure, say, results always are same for `toggle=True` or `toggle=False`.

Even though we switch to use tensor name, we'll still meet the dilemma if only structure is changed:
```python
c0 = ...

if toggle:
   v1 = tf.Variable(...)
   c1 = ...
else:
   c2 = ...

v = tf.Variable(...)  # undetermined
```
